awd_titl_txt: 2022 Cellular and Molecular Fungal Biology: Gordon Research Seminar
awd_abstract_narration:
The award will provide support for early career scientists, including graduate students and post-doctoral researchers, to attend the 2022 Gordon Research Seminar (GRS) on Cellular and Molecular Fungal Biology (Holderness School, New Hampshire), just prior to the corresponding Gordon Research Conference. These conferences bring together diverse scientists who study fungal biology at different scales (molecules to populations) and from different disciplinary perspectives (genetics, molecular and cellular biology, biochemistry, immunology, evolutionary biology, systems and synthetic biology, etc.) The research advances basic knowledge about fungi, including their interactions in complex host and environment systems, and their evolution, which has implications for biotechnology, agriculture and medicine. The GRS serves as a forum for junior US and international scientists to present unpublished research, exchange ideas and resources, benefit from career mentoring, and build their professional network. The GRS is organized and co-chaired by two post-doctoral scholars, which serves as a significant career development experience. 

The GRS and associated GRC will advance research on fungi, integrating classical cell and molecular biology and modern data-rich approaches. Investigators from around the world will have the opportunity to discuss pioneering ideas in the field and potentially launch new collaborations. The GRS in particular will facilitate training and professional development of a diverse group of scientists in the field of fungal biology.

This award is co-funded by the Genetic Mechanisms and Cellular Dynamics and Function programs in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences of the Directorate for Biological Sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Gordon Research Seminar (GRS) on Fungal Cellular and Molecular Biology was held at the Holderness School in Holderness, New Hampshire from June 25-26, 2022. The GRS was a unique forum for graduate students, post-docs, and other scientists with comparable levels of experience and education to present and exchange new data and cutting edge ideas.

The focus of this GRS was on innovations in genomic, pathogenic and signaling research being conducted using a multitude of experimental fungal models. The seminar highlighted the diversity in the fungal research community by bringing together an international group of early career scientists to be immersed in discussing current fungal biology research with a focus on non-traditional fungal model systems. Comparing the biology and symbioses of many different fungi provided a framework to exchange ideas around fungal pathogenicity, genomics and signaling systems which can be applied to the study of many organisms including those with human health outcomes and ecologically important functions.

The funds were used to support attendance of early career members of the community and lowered the barrier to participation in the Gordon Research Conference which followed this meeting (July 27-July 1, 2022). Together these events enabled participants to build strong links within the mycology, fungal biology, cell and molecular biology, and genomics researchers that make up this diverse field. The GRS included talks chosen from the applicant pool, a poster session, and a mentorship panel discussion with leading fungal researchers. The dynamic of the GRS, with its small meeting size, enabled a strong sense of community to develop and for easy exchange of ideas, critical and constructive feedback, and networking between members of different career stages. The GRS community also maintained a sense of identity through the larger GRC conference that followed. It was clear the participants had gained confidence through the presentations and active conversations around research that were sparked through the conference and at the conclusion of the meeting the participants had built a strong sense of community and intention to stay connected to the research programs.
